title: Huge anti-Brexit message ploughed into field by campaign group
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

This huge anti-Brexit message reading ‘Britain now wants to Remain’ has been ploughed into a field in Wiltshire.

Campaign group Led by Donkeys created the message in 40-metre high letters so it is visible from passing aircraft.

It has been timed to coincide with the People’s Vote march in London today and the crucial vote in Parliament on the Prime Minister’s Brexit deal.

Led By Donkeys released a film of the message shot from a helicopter, with a voiceover by ex-Leaver Lisa Dodd.

She said: ‘I voted Leave because of the NHS. I just can’t believe I fell for it.

The Brexit protest message which has been ploughed in 40metre high letters in a Wiltshire field (Picture: PA)

‘Manipulated wasn’t I, well and truly. I wonder how many more? People say to me, about 17.4 million people voted for this and that’s what they want.

‘I’m one of those 17.4 million and that is not what I want, that is not what I voted for. I want my vote back. I’ve had my vote stolen and I want it back.’

David Lewis of Manor Farm, Water Eaton, Swindon, where the protest message has been ploughed, said: ‘Brexit would be just awful for farming.

‘So many farmers voted Leave but have since realised they were had. It gives me real pride to see this huge message ploughed out in our field. I hope the people in London get to see it. This country has changed its mind.’

In December last year Led by Donkeys was formed by four current or past Greenpeace members – James Sadri, Oliver Knowles, Will Rose and Ben Stewart – to protest against Brexit.

The message was created by Led by Donkeys ahead of the crucial Brexit vote in the House of Commons (Picture: Led by Donkeys)

The group started posting billboard advertisement featuring recent statements from politicians which undermined their current stance.

Mr Knowles, one of the founders, claims that a YouGov analysis of 300 polls shows a majority of Britons would now vote to stay in the European Union.

The name Led by Donkeys is a play on a famous phrase ‘lions led by donkeys’ used by a German general Erich Ludendorff to highlight the bravery of British soldiers and officers in the First World War but the incompetency of its generals.
